title: Thursday, 28th April, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE

Hi. Welcome to Markets Live.

BE

BE

Quite a hot take there from Charles Moore at the Spectator.

11:05 am
BE

An enjoyable aspect of the EU referendum campaign is the nervous condition of the Financial Times. Unable to maintain its usual pretence at judicious balance under the strain, it has become the Daily Mail of the Europhile global elites, warning of the Seven Plagues which will afflict us if we vote to leave. Rather as the Mail loves the headline beginning ‘Just why…?’, so the FT all-purpose referendum headline begins ‘Fears mount…’

BE

The only "Fears mount" headline we've had in the past three months was "Fears mount for British trees after mild winter", but whatever. Onwards!

BE

Its star columnists like Philip Stephens and Janan Ganesh pour withering scorn on Eurosceptic ‘nostalgists’ and bigots. Although they — and most of the paper’s writers — are highly intelligent, it does not occur to them to take seriously arguments which, in other contexts, they would mind about, like the age-old question of who exercises power on behalf of whom. They do not realise, to adapt Matthew Arnold, that the sea of EU faith was ‘once, too, at the full’, but now isn’t. Their cries are part of its melancholy, long, withdrawing roar.

11:05 am
BE

Cripes!

BE

So the FT's extensive Brexit coverage is here. https://next.ft.com/eu-referendum

BE

And Dover Beach, by Martin Arnold, is here: http://www.poetryf...poems/detail/43588

11:06 am
BE

It's all about a man who looks across the coast at Calais, in the dark ...

BE

... and scares himself with thoughts of how barbaric and stupid the people in other countries are.

BE

Draw your own conclusions, I guess.

11:07 am
BE

(@Shinshin: my luxury home is worth approximately £75000, since you ask.)

undefined
BE

Oh, I should say at the top that Paul's AWOL again.

11:08 am
BE

Some conference. Citi, I think. Wasn't really listening.

BE

Which means you have me and me alone to guide you through this busy day for results and such.

BE

Starting at the top, FTSE's rallied a tad but remains pretty dull. Mostly ex-divs.

BE

(@Otter: if I remember my Highers correctly, the great thing about Dover Beach it that it can be about whatever one chooses.)

Legal & General Group PLC (LGEN:LSE): Last: 224.70, down 13 (-5.47%), High: 227.40, Low: 223.20, Volume: 7.26m
Relx PLC (REL:LSE): Last: 1,187, down 35 (-2.86%), High: 1,204, Low: 1,185, Volume: 1.24m
11:11 am
BE

Merlin not autopricing, but you get the idea.

BE

On the other side of the page, Anglo confirms it's sold something.

BE

As in the Brazil fertiliser stuff. Good price too. $1.5bn, or $1.4bn after CGT.

11:12 am
BE

Sellside was mostly hugging $1bn

BE

In that context, Anglo rally's a bit meek ......

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 715.50, up 18.6 (+2.67%), High: 729.00, Low: 700.70, Volume: 3.13m
11:13 am
BE

........ though one also has to add in the highly suspicious 5% rally it did late yesterday, and which we noted overnight, on imminent news.

BE

So, anyway. Good start to the $3-4bn of divestments it needs to take net debt below $10bn by the end of 2016, from $12.9bn end 2015.

BE

Though it's also worth noting that Anglo's selling the good stuff first.

11:13 am
BE

Here, via a recent Credit Suisse note, is the disposal group.

BE

BE

CS adds this morning .......

11:14 am
BE

The next most likely sale in our view is the coking coal assets in Australia at a similar valuation range (CS valuation $1.0-
1.6bn). After this, individual asset sales become more challenging and smaller scale but the company appears on track to hit its 2016 divestment proceeds target of $3-4bn. [...] if the company achieves its sales targets, raising equity becomes increasingly unlikely.

BE

Cash flow and leverage: at spot prices, largely due to the recovery in iron ore and diamonds, we expect FCF to recover to c$1.5bn in 2017E and net debt:EBITDA to drop below 2x. Under our more conservative assumptions FCF is $1.2bn and net debt:EBITDA 2.2x (within the company's target of 2-2.5x). Adjusting for $3bn of divestment proceeds at an average multiple of
6x, FCF would drop to $1.0-1.1bn and net debt:EBITDA to 1.8-1.9x. Only under our downside case ($35/t iron ore) does leverage remain an issue at 3.1x in 2017 or 2.6x post $3bn of divestments. Our review of the group's liquidity position shows the company does not need to re-enter the debt markets until 2019/20 but it would likely aim to re-enter the bond market sooner (2017), in our view

BE

Note Glencore's recent action, incidentally, which suggests the bond market isn't completely closed to miners (or whatever you want to call Glencore)

11:15 am
BE

JP Morgan also.

BE

We estimate the Niobium & Phosphates assets will generate an average free cash flow of slightly under $100m pa in the coming years, for a DCF valuation of $833m (end ‘16E); including potential growth projects we estimated ~$1.1bn could be achievable. The $1.5bn deal agreed with China Molybdenum Co, at around 8x FY15/16E EV/EBITDA (ex ~$10m of AAL corporate costs allocated to the unit), should therefore positively surprise the market in our view.

BE

 Balance sheet implications: post 15% Brazilian capital gains tax we estimate $1.4bn in proceeds to Anglo American. Assuming deal completion during H2’16, we estimate Dec’16E net debt would fall ~$11bn if current spot commodity prices persist and ~$11.6bn on JPMe base case, representing a significant step towards AAL’s target of
less than $10bn in net debt by year-end. Spot net debt/EBITDA post this sale falls to a relatively comfortable 1.8x, but a more stretched 3.2x on JPM’s more bearish base case forecast for commodity prices.

A solid start to disposal process, putting less pressure on coal sales: this deal represents ~43% of AAL’s targeted disposal proceeds of $3-4bn. In order to reach the bottom end of this target we estimate AAL would need to achieve an unchallenging 5.6x FY16E EBITDA for a $1.6bn price tag on the coal assets identified for sale (Grosvenor,
Moranbah and Cerrejon). Or a more ambitious 9.1x to achieve $2.6bn, for total disposal proceeds of $4bn.

 Valuation looking less stretched: we remain UW on AAL given our view that recent commodity price strength is fundamentally unsustainable. Valuation support is, however, evident, with AAL trading on spot 2.7-9.7% FCF yield and 5.8-4.9x EV/EBITDA for FY16-17E, even before factoring in disposal proceeds. A base P/NPV of 0.73x (predisposals) is the cheapest among the peer group.

11:16 am
undefined
BE

ROTR, why are you talking Rocket?

BE

Down a mere 7% this morning.

11:18 am
BE

There's a Merrill downgrade around, which I don't have to hand because Merrill's being a bit funny right now.

BE

(Readers, you know my email.)

BE

There's also this report about Paymill seeking a buyer.

11:19 am
BE

Neil Campling at Aviate takes this as his cue.

BE

Fintech is, allegedly, all the rage. Not for Rocket backed payment solution platform Paymill it would appear. The company has signed preliminary insolvency proceedings in the last 24 hours. Now admittedly not all Rocket backed investments would be expected to succeed given the very risk profile of early stage ventures. However, given Paymill had three previous financing rounds (and 1,800 corporate clients) perhaps this latest development is further evidence of struggles Rocket companies have in raising financing - either at significantly reduced rates or at all. And given Rocket's self-defined key KPI, LPV, is based on post money last financing rounds the risk of down rounds would have a material effect on LPV calculations. It is worth noting that there has been 61 DOWN ROUNDS in the industry since the start of last year (CB Insights tracking data). In contrast Rocket's LPV has increased from €2.3 billion to ~€6 billion in 18 months.

BE

I note, by the way, that HelloFresh is back in Defcon-five marketing mode.

11:21 am
BE

Can't walk through West Hampstead without getting a £40 token.

BE

And they've taken to setting up a little trestle of groceries at Bank station, to show what your food parcel will contain.

BE

One assumes this means it's heading back towards an IPO roadshow. Though whether they'll stuff anyone with it successfully this time remains a trickier question.

There's a little back story here ....

11:25 am

BE

Or, simplified over the longer term ....

11:26 am
BE

Well done everyone.

BE

As of today, Goldman has found out about the internet and is a bit worried about it.

BE

There's a sector note attached. Here's the Next bit.

11:27 am
BE

We downgrade Next to Sell from Neutral. We expect the structural headwinds
that are facing apparel retail from online channel-shift and trading down to
stall Next’s EBIT growth. In addition, the recent negative combination of
declining UK ASPs (trading down activity) and the early signs of declining
apparel volumes, increase the chance that UK apparel demand could fade
further, rather than recover this autumn/winter. In this context, we lower our
target EV/EBIT multiple to 9x FY18E. Our 12-month price target falls to 5,000p
from 6,400p and we downgrade the shares from Neutral to Sell.

BE

Catalyst
1Q16 sales are due on May 4, 2016: We forecast flat Next Brand sales across
1Q, equating to a 2.1% decline in LFL Next Brand sales, driven by 1Q total
Retail sales -1.5% (LFL -5%), and Directory +2%. This assumes a c.3% sales
growth contribution from Next Overseas and The Label, hence our 1Q
forecast assumes a Next Directory UK sales decline of 1%.

BE

Valuation
Our earnings estimates are unchanged. However, in the context of our more
cautious view on Next’s earnings growth outlook, given the structural
headwinds from increased online (see Apparel retail 2025, also published
today), discount and international retail capacity (resulting in limited EBIT
growth potential from here), we have reduced our target EV/EBIT multiple to
9x FY18E (from 11.5x) in line with the group’s 10-year average, and
equivalent to an 8% free cashflow yield. This drives a decrease in our
12-month price target to 5,000p (from 6,400p). We downgrade our rating to
Sell in the context of limited upside relative to peers (an average 18% for
our European general retail coverage).

11:28 am
BE

(@Roddy: thanks, sir, much appreciated.)

undefined
BE

TheDubliner asks about Kenmare ......

11:31 am
BE

Down 6% at pixel, but on a spread of 0.8-0.85, which tells you more than the midprice move.

So they're talking to King Ally Holdings of BVI to raise $100m

As part of a wider $275m capital restructuring, upscaled from the $175m it needed in December

11:04 am
BE

The daily markets liveblog of the Daily Mail of the Europhile Elite.

BE

Cazenove can take up the story from here.

BE

The total equity to be raised raising represents greater than 7x the current
market capitalisation and, assuming the full $275m is raised by YE’16, would
still show pro-forma ND/EBITDA (JPME base case) greater than 15x, although we note
deleveraging does occur significantly thereafter. The net impact, if successful,
will be a reinjection of capital into a significantly de-geared business and the
increased proportion of equity should reduce the level of debt equitisation,
which would be an incremental positive, in our opinion. However, risks
remain, particularly around obtaining existing shareholder approval and
reaching an agreement from the project lending group.

11:34 am
BE

Note, FY results and a Q2 trading update both due tomorrow morning.

BE

JPMe is for $-4m EBITDA, $-53m underlying NPAT, and net debt of $328m.

BE

We view the proposed recapitalisation and (partial) debt
equitisation as the most credible route in which KMR can address its capital
structure issues. Significant risks still remain, however, particularly around
obtaining existing shareholder approval, agreement from the project lending
group and working capital requirements.

11:35 am
BE

Well, yeah.

BE

YE net debt of $342m, cash of $14.3m

BE

And lenders still not agreeing to anything.

11:36 am
BE

It's just a rescue. The fact that there's still a shareholder stub left over is more of an anomaly than an investment case.

undefined
BE

What else is there? We can turn to results in a bit, I guess .........

11:38 am
BE

First, though, looks like Rolls is up on this Telegraph story.

BE

Rolls-Royce considers secret plan to boost profits by £1bn

BE

Coo!

11:38 am
BE

Rolls-Royce bosses are seeking to eke out even bigger savings from the embattled engineering business, according to a secret internal report.
Consultants from Bain & Company are understood to have delivered a study to top executives at the FTSE 100 group, saying it could boost profits by £1bn and match the profitability of US rival GE.

BE

http://www.telegra...st-profits-by-1bn/

BE

Well, it's a secret-ish report.

11:38 am
BE

Except perhaps to people who read Peggy's story that ran halfway through yesterday.

BE

https://next.ft.co...-b0f1-61f222853ff3

BE

W'evs though. Here's JP Morgan to say the direction of travel is quite reassuring.

11:39 am
BE

Over the last four to five months, RR’s CEO Warren East (since July 2015)
has implemented a number of initiatives that should help RR to improve its
profitability. The journey will be long and there are many challenges to
overcome, but we believe all the actions being taken are the right ones.

BE

So, in addition to the Bain report ............

BE

 Deal with German workers: On April 24, the FT reported that RR has
struck a four-year deal with German employees in its Power Systems
division (formerly Tognum). RR has agreed not to impose compulsory
redundancies before 2020 and to reduce the proportion of contract workers
from 8% to 5% by 2019. In return, employees agreed to changes in working
practices, voluntary severance (up to 550 jobs), increasing or reducing hours
according to workload, and flexible working. RR expects to save up to €10m
pa., according to the news report.
 New Senior Independent Director: On April 4, RR named Sir Kevin Smith
as its new SID. Sir Kevin was formerly chief executive of engineering group
GKN and has been on the board of RR since November 2015.
 Giving ValueAct a seat on the board: On March 2, RR agreed to give
activist investor ValueAct a seat on its board.
 Eliminating managerial roles: On March 10, the FT reported RR had cut
150 management jobs, under Mr East’s plan to take out roughly 400 of the
group’s 2,000 most senior management roles. The FT said the next round of
at least 200 cuts is expected before the summer.
 Removing heads of super divisions: In December 2015, Mr East
eliminated the two “super divisions” which sat above the five main
operating divisions. The heads of the “super divisions” have both left RR.
The aim was to bring Mr East closer to the operating units.

11:40 am
BE

That's the JPM summary.

BE

He's extremely capable, Mr East, but he's also fighting quite a few fires simultaneously.

undefined
11:43 am
BE

Also pre results, should mention Victrex.

Victrex PLC (VCT:LSE): Last: 1,417, down 101 (-6.65%), High: 1,431, Low: 1,294, Volume: 599.29k
BE

And the news that it's come to a resolution with the FTC on exclusive long-term contracts
for Invibio products

11:44 am
BE

You can get the full judgement text here: https://www.ftc.go...ctrex-analysis.pdf

BE

Which is, as is the nature of these things, very complicated indeed.

BE

Barclays has a summary of main points.

11:45 am
BE

The consent agreement requires Invibio (Victrex’s medical devices business) to cease and desist from enforcing exclusivity terms in most current supply contracts and generally prohibits Invibio from requiring exclusivity in future contracts. There are exceptions for certain projects where Victrex is working with customers on custom components and when developing new applications such as trauma and knee (two of Victrex’s pipeline projects). The order also prevents Invibio from adopting other mechanisms such as market share discounts or volume discounts to maintain its monopoly power.

· The FTC alleges that, after first receiving approval from the US FDA to sell PEEK for implantable medical devices in 1999, Invibio sold PEEK to its customers under long-term supply contracts which regularly included exclusivity requirements. After a period of effective monopoly the FDA cleared the first spinal implant device using Solvay PEEK in 2010 and the first containing Evonik PEEK in 2013.

· The FTC alleges that Invibio responded to this competitive threat by tightening and expanding the scope of exclusivity provisions in its supply contracts to impede Solvay and Evonik’s progress. The FTC alleges that Invibio made concerted moves to prevent Solvay and Evonik gaining reputation and experience by developing their own supply relationships.

· According to the FTC, Invibio extracted exclusivity terms from customers by threatening to withhold supply or support services and by offering minor inducements. Where necessary, Invibio offered small price discounts in exchange for exclusivity. As a result, the FTC claims that nearly all medical device makers that purchase PEEK do so under contracts that impose some form of exclusivity. Taken together, the FTC alleges that Invibio’s exclusive contracts foreclose a substantial majority of PEEK sales from Invibio’s rivals.

· The FTC alleges that Victrex has maintained its monopoly power through exclusivity contracts and harmed competition by marginalizing competitors. It also claims that these exclusivity contracts have deprived medical device makers of the opportunity to make a meaningful choice among competing suppliers. The FTC claims that, without these exclusivity contracts, a significant proportion of medical device makers would contract with Solvay or Evonik to secure lower-priced PEEK.

· According to the FTC the factual allegations in the complaint support a finding of monopolization. Although Invibio’s exclusivity strategy has not prevented entry entirely, its terms have foreclosed its rivals from a substantial portion of available sales opportunities in the relevant market and prevented those rivals from competing effectively. The FTC adds that no precompetitive efficiencies justify the scope of Invibio’s exclusionary and anticompetitive conduct. Any precompetitive benefit could have been achieved through less restrictive means.

BE

The remedial actions require Victrex to:

· Stop requiring exclusivity for any new contract except in cases where Invibio and the customer have engaged in the joint development of a new product that has required the contribution of significant capital, intellectual property rights, or labour by both Invibio and the customer, or when a customer asks that Invibio manufacture a customer component to the customer’s specifications.

· It is our understanding that this provision covers several important pipeline projects such as knee and trauma. The exclusivity contracts must be in writing, time-limited, applicable only to the jointly developed or custom product and notified to the FTC. Sales from these exclusive contracts may not account for more than 30% of Invibio’s total annual sales.

BE

So, direct impact minimal but indirect impact impossible to predict.

11:46 am
BE

The decree was probably sought to put a line under a case that may otherwise have caused a prolonged distraction to the company and management. In our opinion the share price reaction today (-8%) reflects investor skittishness around the competitive environment for PEEK, particularly on the eve of new capacity coming on-stream from Solvay in the US. Invibio’s 88% gross margins are an important part of the Victrex investment case and the division contributed 26% of group gross profit in 2015.

This is a complex case and the direct impact on Victrex’s revenue and pricing is unclear, not only in Invibio but also from potential spill-over effects to the rest of the portfolio. Hence it is too early to tell whether today’s reaction is justified. What is clear is that investors are likely to shoot first and ask questions later. The news comes at a bad time for the company as it battles against headwinds from lower oil & gas demand and weakness in the latest iPhone 6S platform.

There are a number of mitigating factors which are important to consider. We do not believe it is fair to suggest that Victrex’s leading position in implantable PEEK for medical devices is solely down to anti-competitive behavior. Victrex has a long history, deep understanding and valuable experience in the manufacture of PEEK. We believe customers value the high level of service, deep-seated relationships and surety of supply. We also note that this investigation covers sales of PEEK by Invibio in North America and, as far as we know, does not impact bilateral contracts elsewhere. However, this is undoubtedly a hit to Victrex’s otherwise solid reputation.

BE

Though there are several brokers saying, "direct impact minimal, tho"

BE

Such as Credit Suisse.

11:48 am
BE

Impact non-material: Invibio represents 24% of group EBITDA (c£30m) of
which 2/3 is US based (£20m). We estimate 75% of this business is spinal
fusion (selling PEEK material; Solvay and Evonik also qualified to sell in US)
and 25% finished product (no competition from Evonik/Solvay). Assuming
50% of spinal fusion sales are exclusive contracts, this opens up c£7m of
EBITDA to greater competition. We therefore believe the downside from this
ruling is relatively limited.
■ Worst case Scenario: Under a worst case scenario (not base case) we
assume that Victrex may lose 50% of the exclusive contract business. This
represents c£4m of EBITDA. We value Invibio on 9x EV/EBITDA in our
SOTP – this represents c40p/share.
■ Valuation: The intra-day market price of £14/share implies Victrex is trading
on 15x PE and 9.7x EV/EBITDA based on Credit Suisse forecasts. We
believe warranted valuation for Victrex is greater than 14x EBITDA given: 1) competitive
position; 2) barriers to entry; and 3) large market growth potential (greater than 10%
CAGR mid-term).

undefined
BE

Okay, to the risers.

Weir Group PLC (WEIR:LSE): Last: 1,198, up 72 (+6.39%), High: 1,220, Low: 1,164, Volume: 1.04m

undefined

ABBOTT TO BUY ST. JUDE MEDICAL IN DEAL VALUED AT ABOUT $25 BLN

11:54 am
BE

BE

BE

11:55 am
BE

That'd be ....... well, illegal for one thing.

BE

undefined
11:56 am
BE

Sorry, where were we?

BE

Weir Group, right?

BE

Reassures. Bounces. That's that. Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:57 am
BE

1Q16 trading update: Group orders -22% organic (-13% OE and -25% AM).
No change to full year guidance with a guide up in Minerals offset by a guide
down in O&G.
Minerals: Orders -5% organic (+11% OE and -11% AM). Customers continue
to be focussed on reducing operational expenditure and cost per tonne but FY
guidance of organic sales broadly flat vs slightly down in prior guidance,
margins to be similar to last year.
O&G: Orders -47% organic (-40% OE and -49% AM). End markets have
continued to decline. Rig count -20% in last 2M, & expect -46% for 2016. Frac
utilization has fallen to 30%. revenues fell sequentially, margins below zero.
Now expecting slower recovery than prior expectations.
Flow Control: Orders -20% organic (-28% OE and -10% AM). Lower pump
orders on tough comps & declines in mid and downstream O&G. FY guidance
is for positive organic sales growth and flat margins.
Conclusion: Net net we see the guide up in Minerals largely offsetting the
guide down in O&G. Given weakness at Mining peers heading into results we
expect a small positive response from the shares this morning.

BE

Note also the comment about disposals being in progress to raise £100m

BE

Which needs to be seen in the context of recent worries about Weir's balance sheet.

11:59 am
BE

Net debt/Ebitda of 2.7x, by memory, which is not too comfortable.

undefined
BE

And just to clear the last of the requests, Tullow .........

12:00 pm
Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 275.20, up 23.9 (+9.51%), High: 275.80, Low: 253.20, Volume: 6.95m
BE

Stifel saying, "super, but still expensive."

BE

With production in 1Q16 of 65.7kboe/d trailing our full year estimate of 82kboe/d and overall landing ability lowered by c$400m, and the net debt already at $4.5bn overall we see the update slightly on the negative side. Offsetting these negatives are the facts that the loss in production will in large part be covered by insurance (apart from two months of production) and the maturity of the corporate landing facility has now been extended to April 2018 (one year) which in our view was a necessary step in the current oil price environment. At our long-term $55/bbl oil price (largely in line with the forward curve), Tullow's shares in our view remain unreasonably expensive. No changes to our thesis.

12:00 pm
BE

Highlights from the trading statement:
1. Jubilee production averaged gross 80.3kboe/d in 1Q. Even if for the rest of
the year it averages 100kboe/d (which is unlikely given production in April
was also impacted), this would imply a Jubilee full year average of not more
than 95kboe/d. Therefore we expect the new guidance (when announced)
to have an impact of at least 2kboe/d on Tullow previous guidance.
2. The RBL capacity has been lowered to $3.5bn (from $3.7bn). The corporate
facility has also been lowered by $200m down to $800m. However, more
importantly the corporate facility has been extended for a year, which as we
have suggested before was necessary in the current environment.
3. The development of the Kenya and the Tanzania projects have now been
separated. We see this slightly on the negative side, as it would likely
require better economics, especially for the Kenyan project. Therefore, we
are not surprised that Tullow has been quick to state today that the resource
number may increase to gross 750mmboe (from current c600mmboe). More
importantly to us this in our view may also suggest that Tullow's partners
from Uganda are likely not interested in entering Kenya (Tullow has been
vocal in telling the market that it is potentially looking for a farm-down, so
this takes two what we saw as viable candidates likely out of the running).

BE

(@fjp73: not that I've heard.)

undefined
12:01 pm
BE

Hey, look at the time.

BE

Sorry if I didn't see your comment. Rather a lot of distraction this morning.

BE

Thanks for tuning in. At least one us will be back tomorrow. Until then, have a good Thursday.

11:33 am
BE

Which included a $75m placement from the Sultanate of Oman, no less.
